poem:
In Gaza's Wake

Where blood seeps through shattered stone,  
where children's laughter once leapt  
the drone's shadows stitch silence,  
a sky woven with grief.

Beneath the indifferent blue,  
limbs lie lost in rubble's embrace,  
a city crumbles to echoes—  
in the dust, humanity's trace.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Why are chilling testimonies from doctors who have visited Gaza being ignored? | Arwa Mahdawi First come the bombs. A boom, then 2,000lb worth of destructive force flattening everything in its way. Severing limbs, vaporizing bodies, leaving craters full of blood and rubble where children used to play. Then come the drones. As the dust settles, the drones start to swarm, picking off any survivors. Armed quadcopters; ingeniously engineered killing machines hunting for human prey.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
